snippet: As chaos persists in the city’s streets, Cairo’s subway remains a model of efficiency, order and dependability for the three million people who ride it every day.
abstract: Cairo Journal: though chaos persists in the city's streets, Cairo's subway remains a model of efficiency, order and dependability for the three million people who ride it every day. Photos (M)

byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM; Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: CAIRO -- By the dusty factories at the end of the subway line, two day laborers emerged from the cars, dreading their return to life above ground. The subway had taken them in no time across the city, underneath the broken metropolis and its maddening obstacles, from one sleek station to another. The rest of the journey home, in a microbus or a car, would not be so pleasant. ''Transportation,'' said one of the men, ''has become more exhausting than work.''

headline.main: Underground, Everything That Life Above Is Not

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )
